body_html:
@acrosson Yes I did, first there was an error in my function, one should change the following line:

posx, posy = tf.meshgrid(tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = height), 
                             tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = width))

to

posx, posy = tf.meshgrid(tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = height), 
                             tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = width), 
                             indexing='ij')

Also, this behavior tends to happen for some reason. I found out two possible ways of avoiding it:

  • Reduce your learning rate
  • Add dropouts after your Spacial softArgMax layer

Hope this helps.

Also, this behavior tends to happen for some reason. I found out two possible ways of avoiding it:

Reduce your learning rate
Add dropouts after your Spacial softArgMax layer

Hope this helps.
body:
@acrosson Yes I did, first there was an error in my function, one should change the following line:
```python
posx, posy = tf.meshgrid(tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = height), 
                             tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = width))
```
to
```python
posx, posy = tf.meshgrid(tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = height), 
                             tf.lin_space(-1., 1., num = width), 
                             indexing='ij')
```

Also, this behavior tends to happen for some reason. I found out two possible ways of avoiding it:

- Reduce your learning rate
- Add dropouts after your Spacial softArgMax layer

Hope this helps.
